description:
Macrobrobrachium rosenbergii, commonly known as the giant freshwater prawn or Malaysian prawn, is a species of freshwater prawn that belongs to the family Palaemonidae. It is native to the Indo-Pacific region, with a natural distribution ranging from the eastern coast of Africa to the western Pacific Ocean.

This species is a large, robust prawn that can grow up to 30 cm in length, with the males typically being larger than the females. It has a distinct rostrum (a beak-like structure on the head) with serrated edges, and a pair of large, powerful claws. The body is typically greenish-brown in color, with various patterns and markings.

Macrobrobrachium rosenbergii is an important commercial species, widely cultivated in aquaculture systems around the world. It is known for its high protein content, delicate flavor, and firm texture, making it a popular seafood delicacy. The species has a complex life cycle, requiring both freshwater and brackish water environments for different stages of its development.

In terms of ecology, Macrobrobrachium rosenbergii plays a crucial role in aquatic food webs, serving as a predator of smaller organisms and as prey for larger predators. It is also an important component of many traditional fisheries and sustains the livelihoods of numerous communities in its native range.
